title: There Are No Beginnings, Leeds Playhouse, review: a quietly gripping two hours in the shadow of the Yorkshire Ripper
text:
Is regional theatre in peril? Last year, Richard Eyre urged for more funds to be pumped into this crucial part of the theatre industry. A few months ago, David Greig – artistic director of the Lyceum, Edinburgh – told me the sector was on a knife-edge.

Take a step back, though and, despite the evident cause for concern, there are remarkable grounds for celebration. In artistic terms, the decade is ending on a high. Whether it’s at Bristol, Chichester, Northampton, Nottingham, Manchester or Sheffield, exceptional work is being routinely done: the former’s Touching the Void transfers to the West End next month; the latter’s spellbinding The Life of Pi will do so next year. But there’s also an abundance of shows that warrant a trip to see them in situ.

What was once the West Yorkshire Playhouse – and got rebranded Leeds Playhouse last year – has now just fully reopened following a £15.8m capital redevelopment, enabling it to join the regional premier league after a decade of fitful achievement.

The name-change says a lot – it often felt as though the identity of the WYP was too blurredly regional; and the ambitious architectural rejig brings home who the place is for. Where once the main entrance area faced vexingly away from town, and was an uphill struggle to reach, now a swanky, glass-fronted extension at street-level greets a revitalised part of the city, inviting passers-by to step inside.
